etymologies: late 18th century. Originally from post-classical Latin acervulus (in acervulus cerebri from acervulus small heap or collection + classical Latin cerebrī, genitive singular of cerebrum)

definitions: More fully "acervulus cerebri": a collection of small calcified concretions situated within or near the pineal body; = brain sand. In later use also: an individual concretion of this kind.
In certain fungi pathogenic to plants: a flat, typically round mass of hyphae bearing conidiophores which is produced below the epidermis of the host plant.
